TALK.START.PARA: —I will not speak for long in the adjournment debate tonight. I want to carry on some of the comments that were made last night in connection with the Labor Party factional row in Queensland. I bring to the attention of the House the allegation of bias that was made by the member for Moreton (Mr Gibson) in connection with the redistribution of his electorate.

PARA.TAB: During the grievance debate the day before last the member for Moreton roasted a member of the commission for being biased, and he gave his reasons for that. Last night I alleged that it was not just a matter of shooting at the commissioner but a factional fight between the AWU and the left wing. That meant that he had to argue for changes in his electorate which were not supported by the party hierarchy.

TALK.START.PARA: —Who won?

—You know who wins in the long term in these things, don't you? An article in today's Courier-Mail, headed `Poll boundary bias denied', states that both the officer alleged to have committed the offence, Bob Longland, and the justice involved said that the member for Moreton was not in possession of the facts and did not really know what redistributions were about.

PARA.TAB: It is a factional fight. We have already been given to understand that the first two seats in the Senate have gone to the AWU and the third seat to the left. That is unwinnable. As I said last night, in view of the Canberra by-election result, the Labor Party might get one seat but the second seat is now in doubt.

I come back to the fact that this is not the appropriate place to carry on a factional brawl. If you have a factional brawl in Queensland you should at least get behind closed doors and sort it out. I understand that at the appeal of the redistribution the honourable member for Moreton had to present his own case. The case that was presented by Mr Kaiser was the party line. I suggest, and I think the honourable member might now agree, that it is the thin end of the wedge to give the honourable member an unwinnable seat. He might even confess to that.

I take offence, as I mentioned last night, at the distribution that gave rise to the 1990 election result, where votes were almost 50-50 between the coalition and the Labor Party; but the seat was gained by the Labor Party with 62.5 per cent against our 37.5 per cent. We were not squealing—although we had some complaints about Fitzgerald—but that was the basis of the redistribution. Even the 1991-92 redistribution gave Labor a majority of seats with a minority of the votes cast.

I have always found the commissioners to be fair and reasonable, in spite of the fact that we had an obvious complaint. They have a very difficult job, every three years—because of the increasing population of Queensland—of getting another seat. That is a problem in itself. I always felt that the commissioners went to a lot of trouble with the 1991-92 redistribution as they knew there was another redistribution pending. There was minimal change to boundaries.

I know that the National Party's submission to the commissioner at that stage was that there should have been two new seats around Brisbane, with another seat being abolished. I still believe that should have been the case but I am not prepared to argue the matter further. I just feel it is a sad moment when a factional brawl is brought into this parliament. The people at loggerheads are the member for Moreton and the secretary of the Labor Party in Queensland. It also shows the predominance of the AWU in those factional deals.

TALK.START.PARA: —What about the Attorney-General? Is he safe?
—The Attorney-General (Mr Lavarch) might have been part of the deal because he has a very thin margin. That is a good interjection. I will take it on board. (Time expired)

—During the years of the Second World War, when I was a young boy growing up, and in the years immediately after the war I watched my mother operate an old Singer sewing machine which my father had put an electric motor on. My mother was a textile outreach worker. Later, she managed to get an industrial sewing machine. She worked quite frightening hours under great pressure to keep my sister and me clothed and fed, which I appreciate. I recalled those events recently when I read a report by the felt and textile union on the hidden costs of fashion. Having read that report, the memories of my mother working at home the way she did came back very vividly. Outreach work is not a very pleasant way to work. We should remember that it is mostly women who are forced to work in these circumstances.The report, which was launched on 16 March 1995, is a litany of horror. That is the only way to describe it. It talks of women working in excess of 150 hours a week for less than $2 an hour. Taxation questions arise immediately, as do social security questions. At the very best, it is industrial anarchy. Much of this has resulted from the massive changes to the textile industry brought about by changes in tariffs. Many factories which employed these people under industrial awards and with decent working conditions said that they would export those jobs overseas and start importing most of these fashion garments.

PARA.TAB: What they did was to employ only cutters to cut the material. They then put those materials out to contractors who then contract back to women at home working under these conditions. Most of these women are migrant women. In Victoria a large part of the outreach textile area is women from the Vietnamese community, women who do not understand the industrial relations capacity this country offers them and who do not understand that they do not have to work as they did in their own countries in Third World conditions.

The report should be read by all members. I know that the report is going to be posted to all members of this House. I urge you all to read it and to contemplate what is appearing in this country now. In every city we have Third World working conditions.

Sadly, most of the garments made in these backyard outreach areas are sold in Australia under well-known labels. All of us may be guilty of buying those labels, not knowing the circumstances under which the garments are being produced. I have prepared a list of those labels which are reported to be producing clothes by using outworkers. Rather than read them all out one by one, it is more appropriate if I seek leave to table the list of names.
Leave granted.

TALK.START.PARA: —Among those are names like Country Road. There is an example in the report of an outreach worker producing clothes for Country Road such as a shirt which sells for about $99 retail. The woman at home who sews that shirt up gets paid $6 to $7. The contractor who uses the outreach worker is getting $10. Country Road sells it for $99. My simple view of the world is that that is exploitation of women at its absolute worst. It is something I believe we need to look at very carefully in this country. Again, we need to look very carefully at how we can bring some industrial law back into the outreach system and ensure that women are given equality in their homes.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Worth Ms P.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —I would like to take this opportunity to condemn the Prime Minister (Mr Keating) for his rude, inappropriate and insensitive remarks made to Adelaide University students last Thursday. These students were taking part in a protest against the government. These students felt that they had been let down by this Labor government. As my colleague Senator Hill said in the Senate on 23 March:

SPEECH.PARA: . . . students feel that they have been misled. In fact, students believe that they were lied to at the last election, so much so that their own president said, `The government has lied to undergraduate students claiming that they would be protected from up-front fees.' I understand that this President of the National Union of Students is, in fact, a member of the ALP.

PARA.TAB: That is the extent of disillusionment of students with this government's policies. This is only reflective of a wider community disillusionment with Labor and its performance in office—just another sector of the community that is coming forward and saying, `We were misled. We were lied to in the last election. We will stick it no longer. We must go out there and protest. We must protest against the misrepresentations that were made by this government.'

SPEECH.PARA: Protesting students were asked by the Prime Minister: `Why don't you get a job?' Given that there are 346,000 Australians under the age of 24 who cannot get a job, I am calling on the Prime Minister to apologise to all young Australians. I am also calling on the Prime Minister to accept the challenge made by Haroon Hassan to face a panel of young Australians, including student leaders, on national television. For the record, I would like to read a copy of the letter written to the Prime Minister by Haroon Hassan:
Dear Prime Minister
I am writing to you in response to your comments made to me and other student demonstrators outside the Glenelg Town Hall on Thursday 23 March 1995.

I must express my deep disappointment and the anger felt by other students at this completely uncalled for and totally inappropriate statement. To acknowledge the protests of over 15,000 students in this manner has sent a clear message of contempt to hundreds of thousands of young people all over Australia.

If your Government truly has any commitment to the future of young Australians then you will accept my challenge to face a panel of young Australians, including student leaders, on National television in order to outline your stance on Youth Employment, Training and Education Policy. It is evident the time has come for the Government to acknowledge the valid concerns of today's youth and by accepting such a challenge it would give the Government and other political leaders the opportunity to communicate their views in an open forum. Furthermore, it would allow us the chance to directly respond.

I also feel compelled to address your comments during Question Time on 27 March 1995. The answer you gave to Dr Kemp's question displayed a fundamental lack of understanding of the nature of the National Student protest that occurred on Thursday 23 March. Students were deeply concerned over continued moves toward `user pays' education in particular the introduction of up front fees for Undergraduates and the deregulation of Post Graduate fees.

Students were also voicing their protests over the regressive policy options outlined in the DEET/HEC Paper on `Resource Allocation in Higher Education'. Amongst the options canvassed in this paper was a move towards differential HECS and other changes to the current system which students feel would be as equally regressive as fees. The protest was in no way aimed at `abusing you' about HECS. Indeed, it was an opportunity for students to demonstrate and express their belief and conviction in these issues.

I feel your handling of this issue has sent a particularly negative message to over 500,000 tertiary students in Australia. I offer you an opportunity to redress that situation and to demonstrate a commitment to their futures.
Yours sincerely
Haroon Hassan
President
Students Association
of the University of Adelaide.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Swan Mr W.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —Abuse of parliamentary privilege was, I think until recent times, a relatively uncommon event in Australian parliaments. However, events in the Senate last week and events in the Queensland parliament this week have changed that situation. In the Queensland Legislative Assembly this week a National Party member, Mr Grice, left a trail of slime and innuendo that would have been admired by the greatest practitioner of the dirty tricks game, the late unlamented Senator Joe McCarthy.

PARA.TAB: In his contribution, Mr Grice tossed in my name as an extra. The main target in the contribution from Mr Grice was the Minister for Defence (Senator Robert Ray). The keystone of the Grice case was that the minister attended a meeting in a Sydney hotel in May 1993. Yesterday, Senator Ray in another place devastatingly refuted this allegation. He told senators that he was not in Sydney on that day or at that time but on his feet in the Senate chamber. The minister did not visit Sydney on any day of that month. He had never been in the hotel named as the meeting place in his life.

Mr Grice also alleged that a representative of defence supplier McDonnell Douglas was present at this meeting. Senator Ray stated that he made it a practice never to meet a defence supplier except in his own office with a staff member and a departmental officer present. Any reading of Senator Ray's statement makes it clear that the story of the alleged meeting, allegedly vital to a scam worth millions, was a malicious fabrication either from Grice or from his informants. Senator Ray's response moved a Liberal senator, Senator Alston, to say:

SPEECH.PARA: No-one on this side quarrels for a moment with Senator Ray's sense of outrage, given what is said about him would appear to be manifestly untrue.

It is all very well for Senator Alston to play the unctuous gentleman 800 kilometres from the smear and slime in Brisbane. The allegations were all over the front page of the Courier-Mail and in other papers throughout Australia. Grice had essentially done the dirty work for his colleagues in Canberra, particularly Senator Baume, who was perhaps on this occasion somewhat wary to throw more mud, given the events of last week. For myself, I read into the record a letter I have written to the Courier-Mail today. It states:
Dear Sir,

PARA.TAB: I refer to your story covering allegations made by Mr Grice in parliament. I wish to say emphatically that I have no knowledge of any of the allegations made by Mr Grice about Mr Nick Karlos, as I told your reporter in my conversation with him.
The use of the loaded word `admitted' in your story attributed to me in relation to my brief contacts with Mr Karlos leaves the impression of something improper, if not worse.

Mr Karlos rang me on a couple of matters: first, on a local government matter; and second, on a matter to deal with his hopes of establishing a seafood export business. I gave him some advice on how to proceed and contacted some relevant authorities.

I, or any other member of this parliament, receive hundreds of such requests for routine assistance in a year. Other than that, I have met Mr. Karlos on a few occasions, usually at functions with hundreds of people present. That's the record, no more, no less.

SPEECH.PARA: The facts of the matter are that Mr Grice was seeking to establish some sort of involvement in the events that he referred to in his speech and I simply have none. I knew nothing of any CJC investigation into any of these matters. The letter continues:

However, one point about the conduct of the CJC . . . It seems to me that if a public officer, be they a public servant, policeman, or parliamentarian, turns up in a phone log of someone under investigation and the conversation was of the innocent kind I have described, the proper course, indeed the duty of those conducting the investigation, would be to warn the public officer about that person.

No such thing occurred in my case. The fact of the matter is that the National Party in the lower house in Queensland and the Liberal Party in the upper house here are intent on throwing mud on this matter. They should be exposed for their mudslinging silly exercises.

PARA.TAB: Mr Katter interjecting—

TALK.START.PARA: —I have no doubt that the member for Kennedy will come into this chamber and engage in more of that activity in the not too distant future, which is why I have taken the opportunity to set the record straight tonight. You are, Sir, one of the lowest forms of human life known to politics.

TALK.START.PARA: —I rise tonight to pay tribute to one of the icons of Australian industry—I speak of Akubra Hats Pty Ltd, which is based in Kempsey in my electorate. I recently had the opportunity of attending a joint meeting of the Kempsey Rotary Club and the Kempsey West Rotary Club to celebrate the 90th anniversary of Rotary. At that meeting the President of the Kempsey Rotary Club, Mr Don Watson, took the opportunity to bestow the award of Paul Harris Fellowship on the Managing Director of Akubra Hats, Mr Stephen Keir.

PARA.TAB: Akubra Hats is a family company. It was founded by Stephen's grandfather, Benjamin Dunkerley, and was then run by his late father, who was also named Stephen. The company was moved to Kempsey about 20 years ago. Essentially, Stephen Keir did not go straight to the top of the company. He did a full apprenticeship as a hat maker and completed that in 1959. His father immediately sent him overseas to work as a hatter in the Stetson factory in the USA. Stephen also visited hat making factories in England and Europe. Two years later, he returned to Australia and has been involved in Akubra Hats ever since.
Not only do I wish to make the point that the Akubra is valuable to Australia as a great export earner, but I must say that the impact

SPEECH.PARA: of Akubra Hats on its local community of Kempsey has been absolutely outstanding. It is so good that I believe I should take the time in this place to place on record just what that company has done.

PARA.TAB: I could mention that company's support for the clubhouse of the Kempsey Tennis Club and the heating of the McElhone swimming pool. The entrance to Kempsey is enhanced by two gardens in the ex-services memorial park which Stephen Keir established and still pays for their ongoing support. But the absolutely outstanding fact is that, over the 20 years that company has been there, it has provided a total of $308,000 to the Kempsey community—a really wonderful support. I felt that I just had to pay tribute to that.

It is also interesting that Stephen Keir's interest extends beyond his own front door. It was Akubra Hats that provided the money to enable the Australian Museum to retain `Eric' the pliosaur in Australia. That is just very typical of what Stephen Keir and Akubra Hats have done.

There are 135 employees at the Akubra factory. They are hardworking, they are loyal, they are diligent and it is a really great place to visit. Each of those 135 employees has a family that has not had to leave that beautiful valley to seek an income elsewhere.

Looking ahead to the 2000 Olympics, Stephen has provided a scheme whereby each employee contributes $4 per week and Stephen provides $6 per week to be invested in a fund so that employees will be able to attend the Olympic Games in the year 2000. That is an outstanding effort. I want to congratulate and applaud the work done by Akubra for Australia and by Stephen Keir for his community.

The second point I wish to raise deals with the airport noise problem in Sydney. I have a letter but I cannot name the source for obvious reasons. It is from a very disgruntled senior pilot of one of the major airlines, and in it he says:

The reason I'm writing is that I'm getting tired of Mr Laurie Brereton accusing pilots of "wandering all over Sydney" instead of "flying in specified corridors"—the truth is that in Sydney air space we fly exactly where we are told to by air traffic control. To do otherwise could put your aircraft and others at risk. Needless to say C.A.A. are not going to allow you to keep your pilots licence too long if you disobey their instructions.

The Labor Party, through Mr Brereton, have now promoted a $25,000 fine, if we "make a noise in the wrong area" (you may be interested to know we are not provided with any maps depicting these areas and I remind you we can only fly where we are instructed to fly by A.T.C.)
It is touching how concerned they are for the residents around Sydney re aircraft noise!
In 1995 any aircraft that did not meet the latest limits on permissible noise levels had to be taken out of service.
However the Labor government decided to grant a dispensation against this requirement—the noisy aircraft could be in service, until it was 20 years old, or the year 2002—

TALK.START.PARA: —I welcome any Commonwealth funding for regional development in South Australia. However, I cannot let pass the recent statements which the Minister for Regional Development and Deputy Prime Minister (Mr Howe) made when he briefly visited Grey last week. The Deputy Prime Minister was in Port Augusta to launch the Spencer region's development association, our area consultative committee, which was promised in Working Nation. He had the happy task of announcing $960,000 funding for the region. But a third of that did not seem to fit into the regional development category at all. There is quite an interesting story to tell.

PARA.TAB: Port Pirie Central Mission applied for funding through the crisis accommodation program last year, and applications closed on 30 September 1994. When January came around and the mission still had not heard anything it called my Port Pirie office for help to find out what was happening. My office and the central mission contacted the office of the Deputy Prime Minister for information on the application—any information at all—six times, to no avail. Most of our phone calls were left unanswered.

The central mission faxed the Deputy Prime Minister but that too was ignored. We also contacted the department several times. On 13 March the central mission wrote to the Deputy Prime Minister yet again. The mission had a hunch that he might just make a funding announcement while he was in Port Augusta, and it asked him about this. After all, the Deputy Prime Minister could not turn up in the region without some good news to hand out, could he? The minister's office gave some vague excuses about waiting for a signature from the state government but the central mission was proven right.

The Deputy Prime Minister announced the central mission's crisis accommodation funding on 20 March while in Port Augusta. He announced the funding as part of the overall regional development funding which the federal government was giving to the area. How funding for the Port Pirie Central Mission appeared in the Deputy Prime Minister's regional development announcement is anyone's guess. The more cynical among us might say he needed more funding in his speech to make the $1 million mark for the newspaper headlines.

This episode only demonstrates the government's complete antipathy towards the community and cynicism about regional development. When one examines the regional development funding, one comes away feeling very disappointed. What else is the government spending money on in regional South Australia? It is funding a conference called `Beyond 2000'; an economic development officer when there are already quite a few in the region operating out of local development boards; a tourism marketing strategy when councils and regional development boards have already developed tourism strategies; and gateway signage in a town which has already had a committee looking at gateway signage since last year. The list goes on.

In fact, another third of the so-called million dollars for the region is to set up the secretariat to oversee funding and development. If we take out the money which the central mission received and then take out the money for the government's new secretariat we are left with $350,000 for regional development programs. That is the bottom line. That is what the federal government has given us after the Kelty task force, the McKinsey report and Working Nation. What else can you expect from a regional development minister who admitted in parliament that Working Nation regional development initiatives were modest and certainly not a big spend.

TALK.START.PARA: —It is very interesting to hear the member for McEwen (Mr Cleeland) rise tonight to speak about this document The Hidden Cost of Fashion and the problem of outwork in the TCF industry. My intelligence suggested to me that the member for McEwen was actually going to stick the boot into the TCF industry, name names and talk about government industries that were involved in the TCF industry. However, it seems that the connection between the union and the Labor Party is such that we have to hide a lot of facts on the question of what the effects of restructuring have been on the Australian manufacturing industry. No amount of crocodile tears will obscure the fact that the dramatic reduction in tariffs over the past 10 years or so has seriously affected the TCF industry.

PARA.TAB: In relation to outwork, the companies are not actually identified in the report, but there is a subsequent report that identifies some major Australian companies. Those companies can argue their case at another time. I am not one to get up and name names in the parliament when I do not have the evidence at my fingertips. Some people in the place are quite happy to throw names around without any evidence to support those claims. Senator Baume over in the other House loves that kind of thing.

If it is true that the companies named in the material tabled by the member for McEwen are actually engaged in outwork of the kind that we would find objectionable due to the exploitation of workers, most of whom are from Asian countries and are probably being exploited because of language problems—they are probably female as well—then this parliament has to act on it. The Prime Minister (Mr Keating) has to instigate some kind of inquiry into the level of outwork. I know that the Attorney-General (Mr Lavarch) is with us tonight. He chaired a committee which produced a report entitled Halfway to Equal. The fact is that it is women in the TCF sector who have really suffered in the past decade from the massive tariff cuts that the government has imposed on that particular industry.

I know that there is a code of silence in the Labor Party on tariff policy. It is generally considered that it is reactionary, or there is the idea that it is reactionary politics, Black Jack McEwen and the like, but what we are seeing now is that those tariff cuts have had a dramatic effect on a particular industry and the majority of the people who work in that industry—women—have been thrown on the scrap heap and are now working in the back blocks of Coburg and Brunswick doing outwork and being exploited by pretty nasty employers. We really have to have a serious study of what the effects have been.

We also have to ask the Prime Minister where the alternative jobs are going to come from. The Prime Minister and the Minister for Employment, Education and Training (Mr Crean) tell us that we are in the process of establishing a high-tech Australia, where those people who have lost their jobs in the textile industry and in manufacturing are going to be retrained and are going to participate in Australia's recovery via high-tech industries. But those industries are not appearing. They are not appearing in Wills or Batman, the seat of the Deputy Prime Minister (Mr Howe). They are not appearing in Maribyrnong, in Footscray, in Lalor or, I dare say, in your electorate, Mr Deputy Speaker.

So where are the new jobs going to come from? This report suggests that we are not creating new high-tech jobs. We are creating a Dickensian nightmare out in the old working class territory that has traditionally voted Labor. These companies that are listed and tabled in the report by the member for McEwen will have to answer those complaints. They will have to tell us whether or not they are actually exploiting workers.

I know that the Leader of the Opposition (Mr Howard) talks about a new Australia where the family is going to be protected and where we will have different kinds of contracts and we will free up the labour market. But is freeing up the labour market equivalent to sending people into outwork and destroying family life? Conservatives cannot have it both ways. If you free up the labour market to such an extent that people are sent out into the back blocks to do outwork without the protection of the union, you destroy the family.

The Leader of the Opposition has to address this problem, just as the Prime Minister has to address the consequence of this economic restructuring because the facts are, as presented in this report and only touched on by the member for McEwen, who wanted to step daintily around the problem, that we have some serious problems in manufacturing.
Question resolved in the affirmative.

DEBATE.SUB1.TITLE: Shipping in and around the Great Barrier Reef

PARA.TAB: Debate resumed from 7 March, on motion by Mr Beazley:
That the House take note of the paper.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Braithwaite Mr R.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —I am pleased to be able to speak on the ministerial statement about shipping in and around the Great Barrier Reef. Of course, this has a great Queensland flavour and is of very great Queensland interest. It is appropriate that it should be brought forward in this chamber, particularly one day after the spectacular success of our cricket team in winning the Sheffield Shield—a great Queensland initiative. I am sure that this success will flow on, with the proposals before us, also to the success of the Broncos in the Winfield Cup competition as we have already won the Tooheys Challenge Cup. I know this is slightly irrelevant—
—I hesitate to remind the honourable member that the question before the Committee is that we take note of the paper, not praise Queensland.

—Yes, I am coming to that. I was just going to mention that the cowboys are particularly interested in North Queensland. Of course, they operate out of some of the major ports in North Queensland that should have access. I thought my remarks would be relevant in that respect.

PARA.TAB: My own electorate of Dawson has about 500 kilometres facing the Great Barrier Reef. Others will dispute which is the best part of it but I do not think anybody can dispute that the whole reef is known as a world asset and is one of the natural wonders of the world. I think the part facing my electorate would pretty well be classed as being the best of it. So the need for its protection is paramount, as the statement has suggested. Each of us would have a concern about it. I believe that Queensland shares that with the rest of the world—North Queensland certainly shares it.

The purpose of the statement is to guarantee further safety by diverting the shipping traffic further out along the outer barrier reef, instead of the inner barrier reef—the Whitsunday Passage forms part of that inner reef. But I caution the Minister for Transport (Mr Brereton) that there are still dangers on the outside reef. The seas are larger, the reef is still there and there are abutting reefs that have to be carefully missed if this is going to be a success. I suggest to the minister that one of the biggest problems in this traffic route is that of the Torres Strait islands. I have never been there but I believe that most wreckages associated with the reef have been at that neck of entry where the Pacific Ocean meets the Indian Ocean. The turbulence there, I believe, is one of the major concerns. I believe that the major tanker disaster of a couple of decades ago occurred in that area.

Of course, we have progressed since then, one would think, but there is still a danger and a great need for pilotage through that area. One would hope that it had improved but I think the Ships of shame report indicated otherwise, that there is a major problem with vessels that are now sailing the world routes. Some of those international ships come through those reefs and I know it is the position of the government to make sure that those boats are properly surveyed. But there are occasions when this does not happen, and removing those from any influence on the reef is to be endorsed.

What does concern me a little about the statement of the minister is that, at no stage, does he acknowledge that the Hydrographers Reef already provides access from the inner reef to the outer reef. It uses Dalrymple Bay, Hay Point and Mackay harbour. All of those are accessible by the Hydrographers Passage, which was subject to a report by the Public Works Committee about 10 years ago. It was opened for that traffic; otherwise the ships had to go right down to Gladstone, go around the reef and come back. I do not see why that should not be mentioned in the minister's statement because it is a major access from the outer to the inner reefs. The minister says in his speech:

SPEECH.PARA: Each year 30 loaded oil tankers enter the Torres Strait and transit the inner route . . . The government considers that there is no compelling reason—
a tautology if I ever saw one—
for those 30 tankers not to join the 20 tankers using the outer route.

I think what he is saying is that the government is going to put those 30 tankers on the outside route. Why he did not say it in that language I do not know, but what concerns me is that there are ports inside the reef. I believe that Gladstone can always be accessed because it is right at the end of the reef, but we have Port Alma, Dalrymple Bay, Hay Point, Mackay harbour itself, and we have Abbott Point, Townsville and Cairns. I would hope that when the minister is talking about the oil tankers he is not talking about the resupply of those areas, which would occasion tankers to go there. Also, there is a growing trade in ethanol, which is exported out of Mackay—I do not think it would be a danger to the reef, but it does require a tanker to take that fuel off—and there are the molasses tankers. I would like that to be a little bit more clearly enunciated, because I think it is very important in the whole context of things, but we certainly do agree that the move is necessary.

PARA.TAB: The minister has already identified 600 vessels that can use the outside route and not the inside one they are using at the moment. Being able to push them further out is great, provided they understand that limited pilotage might still be required to go past the outer Barrier Reef.

The other thing that comes to my mind is that about six or seven years ago the pilotage of those vessels was let to a particular firm, to the extent that it is a monopoly. I would like to ask whether the pilotage has been maintained at the strict standards required to make sure there is no damage to those vessels on the way through, either through Hydrographers Passage or through the inner reef. I would like to know whether the standard of pilotage is still there, whether the number of pilots are still there, and what the situation is.

The minister also widely identifies other users of the inner reef. The tourist industry has a large interest in that reef, and so do the Queensland and federal governments by virtue of GBRMPA, because that is a joint endorsement of the fact that is a World Heritage area. In those regards, we are looking at preserving the rights of charter vessels, private yachties, fishing vessels and things like that.

That brings me to the point of the GBRMPA reef tax, the dollar a day that is being charged to charter vessels only: a charge on those people who are in business. I have been opposed to the reef tax as a user pays charge. I believe it is an offence to call it a tax under some of the legislation that has been introduced, and that one can be hauled up in court for not referring to it as a charge instead of a tax, but I take parliamentary licence here. It is a tax, and the trouble with it is that it is biased against a particular sector of the industry.

The other thing about it is that it is $1 per head for every visit to the reef, and so a person who is travelling 10 times to the reef in a day has to pay $10. In a charge of $60 or $70 that might apply in connection with a fare on a charter boat, $1 is a very small percentage, but the tax is also applied where the charge might only be $5; and in the $5, $1 is a significant amount.

But the main concerns I have are a concern that it is user pays and a concern as to whether the amount is hypothecated to the proper research and protection of the reef. It is not. Some of it is being applied in administration, and the amount is limited in its extent. The natural corollary of the act as we have it at the moment is that it gives an open invitation to increase the rate. Also, I understand there is now consideration, through a report that has been issued, of including yachties and people like that.

The surveillance of this tax and compliance with the tax are of greater cost to the people who will be paying it than the amount recovered. I would like to know exactly what is going to happen there to protect the reef. We are trying to protect the reef to make sure it is not polluted by any shipping that goes astray. I think we now have to recognise that it is a world asset and it has to be accessible, and we have to have a proper user-pays principle in place there. I am certainly worried about the expansion of that tax.

The other thing that has been brought to my attention is that, while the GBRMPA clearly defines the reservation of the parks, the state is likely to now declare as state waters those parts not covered by the national code, which means that people coming from Brisbane and going through to Cairns or the top of the Torres Strait might have to have in their hand before they leave not only a licence to travel through the Great Barrier Reef Marine Park itself but a handful of licences to take them from one state park into another. I understand this could quite well happen and I am advised by some people who are users and could be potential payers of this licence fee that this is the case.

This ministerial statement is very worthwhile. I certainly approve it and I believe that anybody would give it bipartisan support because the reef is one of Australia's greatest assets and is one of the world's greatest assets. But I have to say that none of this will be any good unless we come to grips with the ships of shame. I believe that there will be people speaking in this debate in connection with the ships of shame. I have evidence of how these boats have operated on the west coast and I believe it is up to the Australian authorities to give protection to the reef to the greatest extent possible by making sure that the survey and the licensing of those international vessels accord with what is required. The last thing we would want is, for instance, a huge wreck on the middle of the barrier reef spreading total destruction right through the reef and onto the shore.

There is a reverse situation too. We have got to make sure that what comes from the shore does not pollute the inner sides of the reef. I know that there will be environmentalists and what they call the greenies saying that the people who use and exploit the land on the coast are vandals in this regard. But I have found over the last 20 or 30 years that people that take a living from the soil, and particularly the cane farmers in that area, are environmentalists in that they realise that they have to preserve the soil because that is their own living and the living into the future.

The practices that have been adopted, particularly within the sugar industry, were emphasised just recently by a report put out by the Queensland canegrowers saying, `Right, this is what we do, but more has to be done.' I think that is an appropriate reaction to what we must do from the shoreline to make sure that the inner reef itself is protected against environmental damage. Within that inner reef I think AIMS has already identified huge nurseries of the sporting fish that go further up the coast. That is in my electorate too, outside the Burdekin. I believe that it is in the interests of those farmers in the Burdekin to make sure that the proper practices are adopted.
Mr Deputy Speaker, this is the first occasion I have had occasion to speak in this chamber—

TALK.START.PARA: —Well spoken, too.
—I am sure the member for Moncrieff would like me to further endorse the efforts of the Queenslanders in winning the Sheffield Shield and also in protecting the barrier reef in the way they have.
—How could we disagree with that?

—There we are; the member for Capricornia even invites me to reaffirm the great victory that Queensland had yesterday. I must say that the South Australians were gallant losers. I like good losers. In fact, I do not mind a bad loser, as long as I am the winner.

PARA.TAB: We endorse this statement and welcome the opportunity to debate it, which we did not have in the chamber. I think this is a great improvement. I look forward to taking part later this morning in the Main Committee debate on the report entitled Taxing relaxing, the report on taxation of the tourism industry, which also has a Queensland flavour.

TALK.START.PARA: —I support and welcome the statement by the Minister for Transport (Mr Brereton) on shipping in the Great Barrier Reef. It is very relevant to my electorate of Leichhardt in Far North Queensland. In fact, in addition to its great natural attributes, the Great Barrier Reef is the lifeblood of my electorate in terms of the tourism industry.

PARA.TAB: I was surprised that this matter is even in this chamber, because it is a little hard to understand what exactly the coalition's position is on this. We have just heard the honourable member for Dawson (Mr Braithwaite) speak. He made some very erudite and balanced statements about the minister's statement. I do not know whether Senator MacGibbon holds any official position with the coalition.

TALK.START.PARA: —He is a senator from Queensland.

—Yes, he is a senator from Queensland. I do not know whether he is a shadow parliamentary secretary and holds an shadow executive position. In an article in the Cairns Post—I presume it is accurate—he is quoted as saying that the shipping protection measures on the Great Barrier Reef announced by the federal government this week were unsafe and a dangerous option.

PARA.TAB: I am not sure what the coalition's position is. Senator MacGibbon said that shipping on the outer side of the reef was dangerous. Of course it is dangerous. That is exactly what this statement is about. Senator MacGibbon missed the whole point. We know the outer side of the reef is dangerous, we know that it is uncharted. That is why we are providing money to have the area outside the Great Barrier Reef charted. Until it is charted, these measures will not come into place. I am not sure whether Senator MacGibbon, with respect, knows what he is talking about.

I understand that the shadow minister, the member for Hume (Mr Sharp), has endorsed this statement, but I am not quite sure whether he has done so in the House. I was a little surprised that he was not here today. Nevertheless, he may have spoken in the House; I am not sure.

We are not quite sure what the coalition is about. Senator Bill O'Chee has made some comments in relation to ballast water. He has made a valid point in that there is a problem with ballast water. The extent of exotic organisms which arrive in ballast water and affect the reef is unknown, but it is certainly a matter of concern. It is not a matter for the minister. It is a matter for the quarantine service.

Damage by infestation of exotic organisms, no matter how they arrive in our coastal waters, is difficult to prevent. Damage by chemicals and oil spill is probably easier to anticipate, because we have better information on cargoes and ship numbers and the probabilities of accidents. But I am afraid that Senator O'Chee was just having a cheap political shot. He did not have anything positive to say about the statement from the minister. He merely attempted to pull a red herring—in this case a micro-organism—across the path of the public.

I suggest that Senator O'Chee, if he claims to represent the part of the world that I represent, would do better to concentrate on the very positive aspects of this statement, because they are the aspects that are of great concern to my constituents. There are some very positive aspects of this statement. Firstly, there is the call by the government—and it can only be a call at this stage, but a very strong call—for compulsory pilotage in the Torres Strait. I have been saying that since I was elected as the member for Leichhardt.

I welcome the initiatives for compulsory pilotage. I have a criticism of the speech of the honourable member for Dawson. In talking about the issue, he ignored the fact that there is a general right of free passage in waters throughout the world. That is the problem we have in terms of compulsory pilotage in the Torres Strait. We cannot make a unilateral statement that we want it. We have to consult with the nations that use those waters.

The same situation exists in relation to the use of either the outer or inner channel. That is why the minister used the language he did in his statement. We can only provide incentives for ships to use the outer channel and disincentives for them to use the inner channel. (Quorum formed) However, we can enforce pilotage, and that is what we have done. We also want to provide pilotage in the Torres Strait. I will return to the topic of the Torres Strait later in my speech.

We are providing resources for charting the outer channel, where some reefs are still uncharted. We also have a mandatory ship reporting regime for the Great Barrier Reef and the Torres Strait which will make the outer channel far safer and therefore, on balance, the best option. We are also offering a lot of high-tech solutions to the problem. Those changes in technology make ship travel far safer and make it far less likely that a maritime disaster will occur on the Great Barrier Reef.

The high-tech solutions include extended radar and the differential global positioning systems which are in use in other parts of Australia. The minister announced that a new DGPS broadcasting station would be established on Horn Island in the Torres Strait. That is in my electorate. After that station has been opened in October this year the use of that system will be compulsory. That will greatly aid the positioning systems. This system is accurate to a couple of metres. It is the system that is used in aeroplanes. We will be able to know where a ship is at any point within either the Torres Strait or the Great Barrier Reef.

A computer based charting system is being introduced. It will also assist in that area. Yet another important initiative, which is particularly relevant to my electorate and to the Torres Strait, is the memorandum of understanding on cooperation and assistance in the event of a marine pollution incident affecting either country, which is currently being negotiated with the Papua New Guinea government.

As I have said in this House before, my electorate is probably unique because part of it shares a border with a foreign country. Mr Deputy Speaker, if you have been to my electorate—and you have certainly been to the Torres Strait islands of Saibai and Boigu—you would know that you can see Papua New Guinea. It is approximately four kilometres away; it is that close. If there was any sort of marine pollution incident—any oil spill in that area—it would obviously require cooperation between the Papua New Guinea government and the Australian government.

Not only are the two countries close but also some of the other islands of the Torres Strait—in particular, Yam and Coconut islands—are close. People feel that they can almost touch the tankers going by because the islands are close to the shipping channel. It would be utterly disastrous for the people of the Torres Strait if there was any major oil spill. We are all conscious of the effect this would have on the Great Barrier Reef but it would also affect the people in the Torres Strait because much of their nutrition comes from marine life—for instance, fish, dugong and turtle. If there was any major incident of pollution, it would add to the already acute health problems of these people.

So that memorandum of understanding is very important. There is the additional issue of the alleged pollution of the Torres Strait by the Ok Tedi mine. Certainly, anecdotal evidence from people in the Torres Strait suggests that the Ok Tedi mine has some effects. They think it affects the levels of lead and other chemicals in the sea life. A baseline study from the Great Barrier Reef Marine Park Authority suggests that that is probably not accurate. Nevertheless, in the future we will have to negotiate with Papua New Guinea about any increase in the pollution from the Ok Tedi mine.

The honourable member for Dawson did make some statements in relation to a reef tax. I want to comment briefly on that because I think it is relevant. Other measures are mentioned in the statement, including priority for research funding going to a bio-remediation proposal to be managed by GBRMPA, and in this way the statement talks about some sort of hypothecation of funding.

I agree with the honourable member for Dawson that a tax on boaties seems to be impractical. I have already made that statement publicly. I suspect that will not get off the ground; it is just not practical. I think it is impractical to suggest a tax that would need someone to run around and chase all the boaties and yachties on the Great Barrier Reef and give them a ticket for their tax. The suggestion that it should come off some sort of licence or registration fee is also impractical because not every person with a boat or ship in my electorate or in other parts of Queensland would necessarily use the Great Barrier Reef and it would be seen as unfair.

I do not object, in principle, to user charges in national parks or marine parks. However, if those charges are levied, I think they have to be levied equitably and I think that hypothecation is important. I know that the departments of Treasury and Finance do not like this but, if we are going to levy charges, it is important that the public has confidence that the money it pays goes directly into research, or directly into the maintenance of the national park or directly into what has been suggested in this report. If people know that the money they are paying is going to go directly into those things, they feel confident and they do not mind paying. If they think it is going into general revenue, they resent it.

The final thing that I will say in relation to this statement is with reference to Natplan. There was a review of Natplan in 1993, and one of the recommendations was the priority of research, which I have mentioned. Apparently, there were 30 recommendations, of which 26 have been implemented and the remaining four are to be completed by the end of 1995. But one of the most important things is the positioning of additional equipment in Far North Queensland. I understand that that is some sort of boom equipment and additional dispersants, and the training for their use. In the past, too much of this equipment has been kept down south, as we say in the far north, and not enough has been kept in Far North Queensland. It is very important, because it gives people confidence that, if there were an oil spill, there would be local facilities able to be immediately put to good purpose.

The other matter is the development of an MOU between AMSA, the Great Barrier Reef Marine Park Authority and Queensland for safe havens for disabled and damaged ships, which is another important thing in relation to any oil spill, something that we certainly hope will not occur. In conclusion, I would commend the minister, who came to my electorate and spoke to interested groups there, including a group in Port Douglas. (Time expired)

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Henzell Ms M.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —I am very happy to assist my colleague the member for Hinkler (Mr Neville) and speak ahead of him in this debate. I certainly know that you, yourself, Mr Deputy Speaker Nehl, have a very particular interest in the Torres Strait and in North Queensland waters, so I am sure that you would be another person who would support the general thrust of the statement of the Minister for Transport (Mr Brereton) on shipping on the Great Barrier Reef. It is always a very positive thing to be speaking on a matter that has considerable bipartisan support, even if there might seem to be a large number of Queenslanders speaking on this bill. Obviously, we all have electorates that abut and include the Great Barrier Reef Marine Park Authority area—as, indeed, does my own electorate of Capricornia, which includes Great Keppel Island.

PARA.TAB: In fact, I surprised the Minister for Primary Industries and Energy (Senator Collins) during a visit he made to my electorate in 1994 as part of Beef Week, when I did some regional ABC radio and talked about looking out to Great Keppel Island. The minister really did not believe that I could see Great Keppel Island and the beautiful Pacific from my lounge room window. But I must assure you, Mr Deputy Speaker, that that is the case.

Those of us who are privileged to live along the Queensland coast are indeed fortunate and, therefore, must speak up responsibly to make sure that this international treasure, which is really a treasure of the planet, is protected. It is not just a matter for the state or even the national government: we have an international responsibility here. Indeed, this point was made by the Minister for the Environment, Sport and Territories (Senator Faulkner), in a press release on 7 December 1994, when he said:

SPEECH.PARA: The Great Barrier Reef contains 1500 species of fish and 400 coral species and now generates over $1 billion in tourism and commercial fishing revenue each year. It is the world's largest marine protected area and contains the largest living coral reef in the world. The federal Government has a national and international responsibility to preserve this great national treasure.
This, in fact, is reiterated in the statement of the Minister for Transport, when he says:
But in doing so we must strike a balance between protecting the natural environment and maintaining viable shipping lanes.

I believe we really need to speak more strongly, as has the minister for the environment, because I have no problem at all with the importance of maintaining viable shipping lanes. In fact, our more recent Australian history of exploration of this area is very significant in terms of what happened to Captain Cook and many other explorers in striking the reef and so on. In my own home town of Emu Park we have a wonderful singing ship, which is a monument to Cook calling in to our area.

PARA.TAB: While there is no doubt that shipping is very important in this region, the absolute obligation we have is to strike the balance in favour of environmental protection, which involves making sure that all shipping movements through the reef are safe and without risk of any major oil spills. That was one of the recommendations in the much quoted Ships of shame, the report of the House of Representatives Standing Committee on Transport, Communications and Infrastructure. The member for Throsby (Mr Hollis) was a member of that committee, and the member for Shortland (Mr Peter Morris) chaired it. I quote item 26 from the overview of the report:

SPEECH.PARA: The Committee is concerned that such environmentally sensitive areas as the Great Barrier Reef are under threat from oil spills from tankers. The Committee recognises the action by the IMO in declaring the Great Barrier Reef a sensitive area, requiring ships passing through the reef to have a pilot.

In fact, as the Minister for Transport says in his statement, we have had compulsory pilotage on the inner route. We introduced that in October 1991 and have undertaken a review. In his statement he says:

Nevertheless, today I want to announce a number of initiatives that will improve the safety of shipping in the Great Barrier Reef and the Torres Strait. The initiatives involve minimising shipping pressure on the inner route; additional steps to improve the safety of ships that use the inner route; improved navigational safety in the Torres Strait; and improving the safety and reliability of the outer route.

This is a very important initiative. The allocation of some $3.8 million to the Australian Maritime Safety Authority to chart the outer route will make a considerable contribution because it is quite clear that of all the international vessel movements only a small proportion actually come into port. I further quote from the minister's statement:

Altogether, there are 2,100 local and international vessel movements annually, including 1,700 through the inner route, 600 of which do not call at any Queensland port inside the reef. This leaves some 400 vessels using the outer route.

It has to be to the advantage of the reef for those vessels that do not require to use the inner route to commute further out to sea, but to do that they must have effective charts and there must be access to pilotage.

PARA.TAB: It is very important that all the shipping movements in this very environmentally sensitive area have the required safety standards. This issue was raised as a central criticism in the Ships of shame report that I referred to earlier. In terms of the flags of convenience issue I quote page 51, paragraph 4.8:

SPEECH.PARA: There is a continuing trend for shipowners to reduce ship operating costs to the lowest possible level and a significant cost reduction can be made by transferring vessels to a `flag of convenience'. . . These FOC registries offer investment incentives and lower tax and wage costs, in fact, some nations establish a registry in an attempt to gain foreign currency . . . The Committee has no argument with the establishment of registries to gain foreign currency, if standards of ship safety are maintained. Most FOC registration rules are flexible enough to allow easy mobility between flags . . . The worrying aspect of this development is that many of these flag states have a poor reputation for enforcing IMO convention standards . . .
This has been of great concern to many members of this House, so it is pleasing to note the minister saying in his statement:

As part of the government's response to the House of Representatives Ships of shame report, targeted inspections have doubled and now more than one in two foreign flag vessels are subject to inspection when they call into Australian ports. This rigorous inspection regime has unquestionably deterred substandard shippers from calling into Australia.

We have to raise that bar even higher because we only have to have one mistake with one vessel that has not been assessed in terms of its seaworthiness. The implications in terms of environmental impact, the cost to our fishing industry and the cost to degradation of the reef are obviously massive and would far outweigh the costs of effectively supervising these foreign flag vessels. I want to see more Australian flagged vessels carrying our export cargo around this country. That would be one way not only to maintain excellent standards of seamanship but also to give our people the jobs they need.

PARA.TAB: Some of the initiatives that the minister referred to in his paper are very important. He notes the cooperation of the Queensland government, the move to make the area safer, particularly the Torres Strait area, and the extension of pilotage. He says that he has asked AMSA to pursue the question of compulsory pilotage in the Torres Strait and that that will now become AMSA's highest international priority in negotiations through the IMO.
The minister notes that 70 per cent of shipping that is currently transiting the Torres Strait already uses marine pilots on a voluntary basis. The minister said:

SPEECH.PARA: Yet there are a number of foreign flag vessels which place commercial considerations before their environmental conscience. We now intend to seek international acceptance of the need to carry pilots in these waters.

That is the point I have been making previously. The same issue is there. There will be some very low quality vessels in terms of their seaworthiness which will have poorly trained, underpaid workers who have little understanding of the environment and the very difficult channels through which they are moving. We have to be constantly vigilant to protect this area.

PARA.TAB: One of the issues that this statement further highlights is the competing uses of this very precious international jewel, and our crown in this area of the world, for fishing and tourism. It has been reported that in 1991-92—and I am sure it has increased since then—a quarter of a million tourists visited reef island resorts. The number of commercial vessels operating has doubled in the last six years. Passenger vessels carried 2.3 million visitors to the region in 1993. Visitors to the reef spend over $350 million a year on island resorts and trips around the reef.

We have pressure from tourism; pressure from fishing; the importance of scientific investigation; the issue, as the member for Dawson raised, of use of pesticides and fertilisers, particularly in the sugar industry; coastal pollution; and development impacting on the reef. In relation to that concern, I mention the Hinchinbrook issue. We do have to be aware that, where World Heritage areas—the Great Barrier Reef Marine Park Authority area—abut other proposed developments, we have to be very clear about the impact of massive changes to the ecosystem.

The boundaries that we draw on maps are not the boundaries of the ecosystem. It is very pleasing to see that commercial fishermen's organisations are now very clear about the environmental damage caused by removing mangroves and the effect that that has on estuaries and their lifestyle.

I will mention something in my own backyard that has come to my attention in the last couple of weeks. There is a proposal to put a pontoon on Barren Island, north of Gladstone and out from Rosslyn Bay, to provide for the possibility of tourists coming by boat, diving off the pontoon and looking at the coral. This is all very commendable but, because it is in a particular zone of the Great Barrier Reef Marine Park, no mandatory EIS is required. There is concern from diving groups, fishermen's organisations and primary industry groups that, if this pontoon were allowed to simply go ahead without a thorough review, there is a possibility that other users would be excluded because of ship safety issues—having a large boat and then smaller boats taking people off to dive and explore the reef.

Whenever we look at a new use of the reef, we have to look at the conflicting use proposals, particularly environmental damage to the reef, because, although we want to encourage tourism, we have to do it in an environmentally responsible way. I commend the minister's statement to the House and say that we have to continue to lift the bar higher to protect this global asset.

TALK.START.PARA: —As the only non-Queenslander to speak on the paper, perhaps I can become an honorary Queenslander for the next 15 minutes. My qualifications for speaking on the paper are that I have made many speeches about shipping in the parliament, I am a frequent visitor to and great admirer of the Great Barrier Reef and I will be up at Mission Beach for Easter.

PARA.TAB: I particularly welcome the ministerial statement which was made on 2 March announcing measures protecting Australia's maritime environment. As someone who has made endless speeches in the parliament about rust buckets trundling up and down our coastline, I have often felt that it was more good luck than good management that we have not had an environmental disaster on the Great Barrier Reef, Australia's premier tourist attraction. The measures announced will substantially reduce the risk of such a disaster wreaking havoc on the Great Barrier Reef, an environment so unique and so valuable, and a place of great pride to all Australians.

The federal government has taken a beating over the last few weeks, unfairly I think, about various environmental issues. Again the measures announced by the Minister for Transport (Mr Brereton) at the beginning of March show that the government does recognise the importance of the environment, especially an environmental treasure which is a source of great pride to us all. I do not know about some of the comments my colleague the member for Leichhardt (Mr Dodd) made, but the statements I have seen by the shadow minister and others have all welcomed this announcement.

As a member of the House of Representatives Committee on Transport, Communications and Infrastructure and as a member of the subcommittee which has brought down the report entitled Ships of shame, I know that the committee members, as well as I, have always been very nervous about the amount of shipping movement that takes place along the Great Barrier Reef. If there had been a disaster, it would have had a tremendous impact on the whole reef. Some people might accuse me of being unnecessarily pessimistic, but it is certainly not too difficult to envisage such an incident occurring when 2,100 local and international shipping movements take place each year, with 1,700 occurring on the inner route of the Great Barrier Reef.

I have always supported ships taking the inner route around the Great Barrier Reef. The reason for that, as has been said in the paper and as other members have said, is that the outer route is mainly uncharted. At least the inner route is a defined, if difficult, passage. It is a charted passage with pilotage. Also, in the cyclonic weather conditions that can occur off that part of the Australian coastline, ships are more protected in the inner reef.

I also believe that, if there is an oil spill or some environmental disaster on the outer route, it will be more damaging than a disaster on the inner route, because it will spread across the whole of the Great Barrier Reef, whereas one is more likely to be able to contain it on the inner route. But I welcome the measures that have been announced.

The ships trundling up and down the coast include the oil and chemical tankers and liquid gas carriers, all of which carry the ingredients necessary to create the possibility of an environmental nightmare. The Great Barrier Reef consists of hazardous narrow channels, strong currents and tides and fabulously beautiful coral reefs. There is also the presence of fishing craft. All these factors enhance the risk of grounding or collisions. We have had a couple of groundings on the Great Barrier Reef in recent years.

Also fundamentally important is the fact that the outer route of the Great Barrier Reef is largely uncharted and, again, poses the possibility of grounding. Given the number of ships using the Great Barrier Reef and the millions of tonnes of international trade transported via this sea lane each year, it is not difficult to see the concerns that many people raise. The measures announced are, I believe, balanced to provide critical environmental protection to the reef, significantly reduce the risk of a shipping incident, with all its consequences, and maintain a viable and very important shipping lane for Australia.

The initiatives announced by the minister in March complement a range of other measures already implemented by this government. In 1991, compulsory pilotage for the inner route was announced, making this route one of the world's few recognised compulsory pilotage areas. In 1993, a detailed review of shipping in the Great Barrier Reef and Torres Strait was announced. The review was conducted jointly with the Queensland government, and a range of interested parties from the shipping industry and environmental groups were consulted.

In September 1994, new administrative procedures for the issue of single voyage permits to foreign vessels were announced, placing an obligation on ship users to ensure safety checks before they charter foreign vessels. There is also an obligation to provide information on the condition of the ship and the qualifications of its crew.

Far be it from me to bring a sour or disgruntled note to what have been very bipartisan and supportive speeches in favour of the minister, but there is a contradiction here. The issue of single voyage permits is increasing—and the honourable member for Hinkler (Mr Neville) knows this, because we both know of a ship that was issued a single voyage permit in his area, at Gladstone. The issue of single voyage permits has increased significantly over the last few years: it has doubled each year.

If we are saying that, before they are issued, there is an obligation to carry out safety checks and an obligation to provide information as to the condition of the ship and the qualifications of the crew, why will Australia not ratify ILO convention 147? If we do that, that will make it compulsory that all foreign ships coming to Australia comply with the international standards.

The government, rightly or wrongly—and who am I to criticise the government—says that there is also a contradiction here, because we cannot say whether the ships are complying with ILO 147 until they arrive here. But I believe that, if we made sure—by ratifying it—that all ships complied with ILO 147, which relates to conditions of crew and pay, there would be no need for this other measure, because we would already have it.

In mentioning these measures, it is important to recognise that these latest measures add to the protection of the Great Barrier Reef. The intention of these initiatives is to minimise shipping in the inner route, improve the safety of ships which use this route, improve the navigational safety of the Torres Strait and improve the safety and reliability of ship use in the outer route.

AMSA will be funding the production of charting maps of the outer reef. That will allow some certainty to ships which currently use the inner route due to the uncertainty about what obstacles lie below the surface. AMSA will also introduce mandatory ship reporting for the Great Barrier Reef and Torres Strait.

AMSA and the Queensland government will introduce a vessel traffic system to cover the northern channel and the Torres Strait. I particularly welcome this. The vessel traffic system will improve and speed up information requirements and reduce the risk of either groundings or collisions. The extension of compulsory pilotage to the north of the reef and into the Torres Strait is welcome. However, the Torres Strait is an international waterway and international negotiations will be required to ensure this measure. I am sure that the government of Papua New Guinea will recognise the necessity to protect its environment and will be a strong voiced ally in any negotiation on this issue, and I understand that it has already supported and welcomed the measure.

The strongest indication that we have that compulsory pilotage to the north and in the Torres Strait will be adopted is that 70 per cent of ships currently using the Torres Strait already use pilots. We require that the other 30 per cent of ships do the same but, importantly, as a compulsory measure. Australia does have an unashamed vested interest in the pursuit of this measure. So, too, do the millions of tourists who come here each year to wonder at the treasures off our immediate coastline. The international tourists have a vested interest in ensuring that the Great Barrier Reef and the Torres Strait are protected and safe.

Oil spills remain the greatest threat to the Australian coastline. The threat is ever present. It is preventable and every reasonable effort must be made to ensure that oil spills do not occur—and I am referring to ballast oil as well. I have always argued that it is most unlikely that we are going to have a major oil disaster with a carrier. One of the real dangers, on the Great Barrier Reef and other parts of the coast, is the ballast, the oil that they clean out. The Auditor-General's Report No. 9—Is Australia ready to respond to a major oil spill?—makes very interesting reading, particularly in light of this debate.

The consequences of a major spill are still visibility represented in the minds of so many people by the unforgettable Exxon Valdez incident in Alaska in 1989 when 36,000 tonnes of oil was spilt. The Alaskan coastline is still suffering from the consequences of that spill. Two years ago, I went to the Shetland Islands—at my own expense, I hasten to add—and had a look at the Braer and had a couple of days looking at the economic, social and tourist impact on that area of the Braer disaster. I was very worried about might happen off the Great Barrier Reef if a similar event happened.

There is another issue I want to touch on. We have said that the oil spill is a major threat to our coastline, and I agree with that, but at least with an oil spill you can see the consequences and, albeit often slowly, you can clean it up. But I share Senator O'Chee's worry about ballast water. I know of areas where ballast water has been brought in and let go. It has wiped out the oyster industry around Eden. I believe it has also had an impact in Tasmania. We have got to tighten up on ballast water coming here. Maybe the ballast should be changed at sea. But I also worry very much about some of the things that are being carried up and down our coast.

Yesterday in the House I spoke, as did other members, on a bill concerning transport of hazardous goods by road. We all made speeches about what would happen if some of these drums fell off trucks and started eating through the tar—which happened in Harden last week—and ate the road away. We all made very graphic and wonderful speeches which have been reported today in every newspaper in Australia. But we have absolutely no idea what chemicals many of the ships trundling up and down the coastline are carrying. If there was a leak, let alone a major disaster, it would make the damage done by ballast water look like a vicarage tea party, because dreadfully noxious things are being carried up and down our coast in ships the condition of which you would not believe.

I urge all members to go and talk to the Maritime Union of Australia or the Missions to Seamen or someone. Go and have a look at some of these ships that people such as the honourable member for Hinkler, the honourable member for Shortland (Mr Peter Morris) and I are always going on about. Someone said to me, `Shipping again, Colin' and yawned. This is a tremendous threat, not only to the Great Barrier Reef but to the whole Australian coastline. Jus as we are going to have a register for the conveyance of hazardous goods on our roads, so we should have a register for the transportation of hazardous goods on the ships travelling around Australia.

Every so often we read about an accident around Hay or Harden, where something has fallen off a truck. If we worry about those sorts of things, wait until we get a big spill off one of these ships off Port Macquarie, or off Old Bar, or somewhere else. Mr Deputy Speaker Vaile, as the local member, the first you will know about it is when someone comes to you and tells you about dead fish on the beach at Old Bar. You will then start worrying but by that time three or four days will have passed since the ship sailed by. We really have to take much more account of the condition of ships going up and down the Australian coast and, indeed, what they are carrying. I welcome the bipartisan support for this and thank you for allowing me to be a Queenslander for 15 minutes—at least I did not have to comment on the cricket!

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Neville Mr P.

TALK.START.PARA: —I say a few words today on the ministerial statement about shipping in and around the Great Barrier Reef. Not only does my electorate have a very close affinity with the Great Barrier Reef but it also has a great affinity with the aluminium industry—hence the transport of bauxite—and with the coal industry which crisscrosses central Queensland. One of the major outlets for that is Gladstone, which is also in my electorate. So, if you like, I wear two hats. I have to balance the two and I do not come here with any preconceived ideas that there are not problems on both sides of this equation.

PARA.TAB: The Great Barrier Reef is an incredible ecological feature of Australia. As the report very rightly points out, there are 2,000 kilometres of major reef and within that there are 2,900 reef systems. So in terms of ecology it is something quite unique. We as Australians should take all sensible measures available to make sure it is protected. Because it is such a magnificent part of the world, which deserves our protection, there is great interest in seeing this wonder of the world. It follows from that that it is a magnet for tourists.

In fact, surveys conducted with people here in Australia have revealed that the greatest single ambition of all Australians when planning a holiday is to enjoy a holiday on the Barrier Reef. I think the last figure I saw was in the upper 40s, and that was confirmed at that time by two independent studies. I think one came out at 46 per cent and one at 48 per cent. So, quite apart from the pristine ecological values, it is a very valuable resource to Australia in terms of tourism, both international and domestic.

To move to the problem in hand, previous speakers have said that 2,100 vessels use the inner and outer routes along the Barrier Reef every year. Of those 2,100 vessels, only 400 use the outer reef route because the charting for this is not up to the same standard as it is for the inner reef. I share with the honourable member for Throsby (Mr Hollis) a certain degree of ambivalence about which of the two routes is ultimately the more dangerous.

There is a very interesting statistic in the report on which the Minister for Transport (Mr Brereton) commented. The report mentions that the risk factor on the inner reef is 2 1/2 times greater than on the outer. However, if a vessel goes down or runs up on the reef and loses its cargo, the risk of dispersal across the whole reef offsets the risks for the inner reef, as the honourable member for Throsby quite rightly pointed out. We now have a system of compulsory pilotage for oil and chemical tankers, for gas carriers and for vessels of more than 70 metres in length, and, providing those high standards of pilotage are maintained, I think the major risks have been largely removed.

Returning to coal and bauxite, the greatest commodity user of the inner reef route is the coal industry, which ships 68 million tonnes of coal from various ports along the Queensland coast. That 68 million tonnes represents 78 per cent of the inner reef commodity movements. We should qualify that by saying that most of those coal carrying vessels do not traverse the full length of the inner reef. They generally travel from the point of dispatch until they come to the nearest break in the reef that will take them to the open sea. Nevertheless, it highlights the point that a vast quantity of raw material, albeit largely inert material, is carried through the inner reef.

Of course, the other big user is the aluminium industry, and 7.9 million tonnes of bauxite comes to Gladstone from Weipa every year. The report describes it as a greater theoretical risk. In some respects it is, but that is largely offset by the fact that the vessels that are employed by QAL for that purpose are coal burning vessels. So the risk of an oil spillage is greatly minimised.
