The bulk of my electorate sits on the southern end of the reef and contains the two ports of Bundaberg and Gladstone. Gladstone is the fastest growing port in Australia. Anything that affects the shipping in Australia or affects the Barrier Reef is of great interest to me and to the vast majority of my constituents. We want to see sensible safety measures imposed, but we do not want measures that would make life intolerable for a range of very important industries.

The people in the electorate of Hinkler recognise the importance of protecting this marvellous natural asset. Legislation last year enforced ship polluters to pay for spillages and damages to the reef. I have described the reef as a totally unique and pristine environmental marine park which is the backbone of Queensland's tourist industry, generating billions of dollars a year for both state and national economies.

I would like to touch on another aspect. In being caught up, somewhat, with the euphoria and—dare I say—the rhetoric of the ministerial statement and the report, we might have overlooked a very important feature. It is the fact that we have still not totally addressed the Ships of shame matter as well as we might.

One of the major issues I have raised in the parliament concerning improving ship safety has to do with the issuing of single voyage permits to foreign dry bulk carriers. Honourable members will recall the infamous visit of the APJ Anand—which my colleague the member for Throsby (Mr Hollis) actually inspected—to Gladstone in September 1993. It had set sail from Albany in Western Australia with a load of feed barley for drought-stricken farmers in central Queensland. AMSA found over 120 defects in that vessel, including extensive wastage, corrosion and structural problems, poor crew conditions and substandard safety equipment. The vessel could not even unload the grain cargo, because its lifting gear was defective, and that caused repairs amounting to $80,000.

Honourable members should remember, too, that the Anand was the prime suspect in a bilge spillage in Albany in Western Australia, just prior to its coming to the Queensland coast. At about the same time, another vessel, the Marine Blue, came from Chile with a load of magnetite. It came into the Port of Mackay with a ruptured anchor locker.

What I am trying to say here is: it is not just the theory of the report or the ministerial statement that solves the problem; it is the will to put in place the features that follow that. In November 1993, I wrote to the then transport minister, Minister Collins, expressing my concerns. The ministry changed, as honourable members know, at about that time. The new Minister for Transport (Mr Brereton) wrote back to me. It was a fairly bureaucratic letter. I will, perhaps, excuse him, on the basis that he might have been just getting into his stride and the department might have prepared the letter and all the bits and pieces. But he said—and it just shows how quickly a sea change can occur:

SPEECH.PARA: Unfortunately, the APJ Anand is a symptom of the international problem which, potentially, results in small numbers of substandard ships participating in the Australian trade.
He went on to say:
The long-term solution to the problem of substandard shipping can be achieved through international action by those having responsibility for ship safety.
Of course, that really says nothing. I do welcome the moves that the minister has now taken to actually make a quantum leap from that position.

PARA.TAB: As those honourable members who have read the report will probably be aware, as of 1 March, charterers of foreign bulk carriers will be required to submit a report on the state of the vessel and the competence of the crew to the Department of Transport and AMSA, before being issued with a single voyage permit. While I understand that it is not as detailed as it would be for a tanker, a dry bulk carrier inspection report is a step in the right direction. To that extent, I commend the minister on his change of heart.

In conclusion, I think the report will be a valuable tool in our proceeding further down the road of safer shipping for the Australian coastline, greater protection for the Great Barrier Reef and an intelligent analysis of the usage of the inner and outer reef.
Debate (on motion by Mr Barry Jones) adjourned.

DEBATE.SUB1.TITLE: Banking, Finance and Public Administration Committee

PARA.TAB: Debate resumed from 27 March, on motion by Mr Simmons:
That the House take note of the report.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr Deputy Speaker—
—Two speeches within an hour!

—Yes, and basically on the same subject. I was a member of the committee which has produced the report Taxing relaxing. I must first of all congratulate the chair, a previous Minister for Tourism. We also had the benefit of the presence of Mr Jull, who was a shadow minister for tourism. I believe that between those two, and with the goodwill of the members of the committee, we succeeded in the task we set ourselves—a very difficult one when we are talking in terms of taxation. We have received tremendous reports and various reviews on this.

PARA.TAB: Taxing relaxing is particularly favourable to Queensland. The report identifies many of the problems that we have within the tourist industry. One must also consider in tourism that the problem was in the definition of what is travel industry and what is tourism. One of the recommendations is to try to satisfy that particular matter of address of the tourist industry so that the proper statistics can be accumulated to allow us to rely on more definite statistics and data to make the calculation.

I am reminded that tourism comes into many categories. I know that Expo 88 in Queensland proved to be a tremendous tourist attraction. I would suggest that the win of the Queenslanders in the Sheffield Shield yesterday will equally prove to be a great tourist attraction for Queenslanders, particularly, in the coming years, in their pursuit of that report. I just make that comment because it is very important that we try to get a proper identification of tourism in the data in the statistical collection so that they can be properly used.

One of the facts given to us during the committee hearings was that 70 per cent of tourism is domestic; 30 per cent is international, and growing. Obviously, one of the terms of reference, that we should compare internationally the taxing regime in Australia on the tourist industry, was of vital concern—particularly to me, as is evidenced by one of the minority conclusions that I arrived at.

I will deal with a few of the aspects for which time was not available to me when this was being discussed in the main chamber. On the fringe benefits tax, I can still recall that right around Australia—it did not matter what state people were in, what geographic location they were in—to sit down with people, enjoying their hospitality, a manager of a hotel had to specifically have invoiced to him the amount that he himself spent in entertaining visitors. This then had to be transferred on to a fringe benefit substantiation claim. Such things were said to us in many cases. The Hilton Hotel, I think it was, said that the cost of compliance in trying to keep track of fringe benefits was $8,700 or something like that, and the return to the government itself from the fringe benefits tax was $8,000.

I happen to believe, and I believe that many of the members of that committee thought, whether they were government or opposition members, that the fringe benefits tax has gone to an absurd situation—absolutely absurd. The fringe benefits were initially meant to be caught in the hands of the individual. The government backed away from that because the nature of such a decision would have affected a lot of blue-collar workers. The nature of the decision was instead to tax the employer, and it appears that when the government believes that the employer can be taxed there is no limit to it.

In addition to the changes already made, one of the recommendations was to look at an award which for safety and health reasons determined that the employee should be given certain things. They would not be fringe benefits. I would go further and suggest that that recommendation also encloses a lot of the awards within the tourist industry where the award actually sets down categorically how much an employee can be charged for accommodation and meals, which would be less than the going rate of that benefit as far as the open market is concerned. It is not dissimilar to the graziers award where, as I understand it, since time immemorial and because of the pressure of the AWU an employer cannot charge more than $2 a day or $2 a week for the particular benefit of being accommodated and fed. I happen to believe that is not a fringe benefit when it is in the award and that is what the motion is about.

I do hope that the government sees its way clear to look at our recommendation. More specifically, it should look at the whole area of fringe benefits to determine what is actually a fringe benefit. I believe that, if someone is in a place like Broome where it would be difficult to get people to work in the tourist industry, certain benefits to attract people to that area are not fringe benefits. I know that in a lot of those places there are no schooling arrangements or there are not sufficient education arrangements for the children. I believe that there is no case to fringe benefit a travel arrangement for the children to get education if it is at the cost of the employer. Similarly, if people live in airconditioned houses, that is not a benefit if they are not being charged for it. In those areas which are pretty hostile, airconditioning is common and that is not a fringe benefit.

The other area that we looked at was the user-pays principle as far as a tax is concerned. That is now being introduced, not only by federal governments but by state governments right across the board. I think it is very important that when we have a user-pays tax or charge this principle should be paramount: how that charge will be hypothecated should be identified. Whether it is a visit to the national park, to the marine park or to whatever public place that charge is being applied to, it should be thoroughly examined to ensure that the charge is not just another tax but can be hypothecated down the line to ensure that the parks are enhanced and the government facility that is being used is enhanced as a result.

I am particularly concerned, as I mentioned in a previous speech here this morning, about the reef tax, as it is commonly known in the area. It indicates how bureaucracy can really take charge of legislation. I understand that it is an offence to suggest that this is a tax on tourists. If people do that and identify it as a charge that is additional to the purchase of the ticket, that is an offence under the act. I think that is ludicrous. If there is going to be a charge, let us identify it and say what it is. It is a tax. It is known as a tax in the GBRMPA areas and the bureaucrats have tried to avoid the use of that word by saying it is an offence under the act.

Here is a tax that is not hypothecated. I would suggest that, if we were to look at the amount of the revenue received and the administration charged by GBRMPA in collecting it and policing it—and policing is a very important part of this, with the penalties that are attached to it—the compliance cost for the individual is out of all range. The fact is it is not charged across the board; it is charged to a particular charter industry where the belief is that it can be picked up in a lump sum instead of taking it from the individuals. It is quite inequitable.

I gave the example earlier that it is possible for people to be charged 10 times for reef tax in the same day if they make separate visits and have separate travel arrangements to go to the one place. It is also inequitable that, in a charge of $80 to $100 that people might pay for a day trip out to the reef on one of these vessels, the dollar is only one per cent of the total. Take a ski-boat operator operating off an island for $5: that one dollar becomes a significant part of the total cost and so it is inequitable.

I understand that, once the legislation is in, there will be an increase in the charge and in the cover and that, again, the bureaucrats will dictate exactly how that money is used. I have no hesitation in saying that there should be some form of accountability; and, within the report, we asked for that accountability and also for the taking into account of the aspect of compliance.

One obvious item that came up, as far as capital equipment was concerned, was landscaping. I am happy to note that the committee agreed that landscaping should be part of the development cost and thus appreciated accordingly. The rollover of capital gains tax is not only an obvious thing that should happen in the tourist industry; it should happen right across the board, as far as businesses are concerned, so that, if the person rolls over a business to get into a bigger one, that should not attract capital gains at that stage.

My greatest interest, as I said before, is in the sales tax. We heard evidence from quite a range of people on taxation, particularly on the subject of tourist buses, vehicles and vessels that carried fewer than 12 passengers and did not have scheduled departure dates. I will give the evidence of one person who would have liked to have bought an eight- to 10-seater four-wheel drive, but who found that, to have fewer than 13 seats, he would have had to pay a 21 per cent sales tax. He had a special coach made so that he could accommodate the 13 seats for $100,000; whereas the cost of the eight- to 10-seater was $121,000—with the tax on top of that. Obviously, people are going to go for the custom-built and bigger vehicle, which is not convenient for their purpose.

Similarly, one bareboat operator said that he had bought the Solo, a 70-foot vessel which slept 13 passengers and departed at regular intervals every Sunday, and it was sales tax exempt. He also had a 40-foot bareboat sailing vessel, the Lady Catherine, which slept eight passengers and departed at noon on any day one chose, and that was subject to sales tax. I believe that the committee was in error in recommending a solution to the land based vehicles but no solution to the bareboat situation.

Evidence was given that the fact that there is no sales tax exemption for bareboats is a discouragement to the production of these vessels in Australia. This was demonstrated by the committee's visit to a former boatbuilding facility, which was closed largely as a result of the inability of the bareboat industry to implement its fleet replacement and fleet growth programs, because of the 21 per cent sales tax. I believe the whole thing is an anomaly, but that is what sales tax is, in general; which again leads me on to many of the comments that were made on the aspect of sales tax.

Evidence was given that, in practice, our indirect tax system is narrowly based, with many concessions and exemptions. As a result, it often involves very high ad valorem duties, and it provides an unequal effect over providers and consumers. It was also noted at one stage by a witness that, because the tourist industry was in its infancy, or else was not here when sales tax was first imposed, the general exemption granted to mining, to primary industry and also to manufacturing might also have applied to the tourist industry, had it been the size of those other industries at the time, and maybe it would have had the exemptions that were required, too.

All in all, it is very important to realise that sales tax—on the evidence given to us—did create anomalies. It was not fair and not equitable. As a result, I believe the only fair conclusion that anyone on the committee could have reached—because of the evidence that was before it—is that sales tax is not an appropriate tax for the tourist industry, or for many other industries.

The committee noted the view of Access Economics that solving these consumption spending defects—that is, the sales tax—can only be achieved by replacing the wholesale sales tax with a comprehensive, uniform VAT which raises the same revenue. It is assumed that such a step for the moment is politically unacceptable. My point is this: just because it has been politically unacceptable, that does not mean to say it is economically unacceptable. We have looked at the 1985 tax review, and we have looked at our own Fightback package, and they were both failed on account of politics. This time, I believe, we should look at it as an economic consideration, and not as one of politics.(Time expired)

TALK.START.PARA: —I am delighted to have the opportunity of making a few additional remarks on the Taxing relaxing report, which was, of course, on an investigation carried out by the House of Representatives Standing Committee on Banking, Finance and Public Administration, of which committee I am deputy chairman. The report may well have been entitled `Relaxing taxing', because the thrust of our whole investigation is that there very much needed to be a relaxation of the impact of taxation on the tourism industry.

TAB.EMPHASIS: A division having been called in the House of Representatives—

PARA.EMPHASIS: Sitting suspended from 11.51 a.m. to 12.04 p.m.

TALK.START.PARA: —In the committee's inquiries we became aware that there were a number of instances of the tourism industry being treated unfairly. Ultimately, the inquiry was concerned with identifying the extent to which that was the case, and our recommendations reflect the fact that we found that there were such instances.

PARA.TAB: One of the problems the industry has is that it is an easy target for all three levels of government. There is a perception—a quite correct perception, I suppose—that the industry is booming in many respects. It has been a growth industry despite the recession and a lot of other things that would have been potentially disadvantageous to it. For that reason it has become regarded in some quarters as a milch cow for government, but we have hopefully demonstrated that now is not the time to embark on a course which will adversely affect the tourism industry at a critical time in its growth.

The tourist industry is important to the Australian economy—I do not think there is anyone who doubts that. Why it has become so important might be a matter of some contention. It seems to me that it has become important in aggregate terms by default. I say that because I do not believe that the Australian economy ought to be as heavily reliant on the tourism industry as it is. The fact is that other industries in Australia have declined in importance and the gap, up to a point, has been filled by the tourism industry.

I would not want these remarks to be in any way misinterpreted. I am absolutely supportive of the tourism industry; I am one of its prime advocates within this parliament. My electorate is tourism based, so better than most I understand the importance of tourism. However, it is a fact that as other sectors of the Australian economy have declined in importance the slack has been taken up by the tourism industry and it has become more important. We cannot be complacent about that and in the long term we need to be developing our manufacturing industries and—I am sure the honourable member opposite would agree—our high technology industries. We need to be looking to export some other things in which we have an obvious advantage, such as health services and education.

So whilst I am an advocate for the tourism industry, its relative growth is perhaps a matter for concern because it has occurred almost by default. It is an important industry to Australia because it employs a lot of people—that is primarily why it is important—and because it earns export dollars for Australia at a time when that is something that we desperately need to do.

The question which the committee was not able to answer—and I do not think can be answered in the current regime—is how important the industry is to Australia. Hence our first recommendation addresses the issue of the need for the Australian Bureau of Statistics to be provided with resources to develop a statistical system for quantifying the significance of tourism. In global terms, we who promote the tourism industry talk about it employing half a million Australians, and perhaps even in the next sentence we could talk about it employing one million Australians. I suspect that somewhere between those two figures there is an element of truth, but the problem lies in defining the industry and understanding what its limits are.

In a tourism based electorate like mine it could probably be said that almost everybody employed on the Gold Coast is in some way employed in the tourism industry. That is probably not quite the case, but certainly a substantial majority of people are. In definitional terms that remains a problem, and until we can point to some really good, strong figures, perhaps we are still not able to sell the industry as strongly as we ought.

The other side of the equation that I mentioned was the overseas dollars that the industry earns. Once again, there is no really clear indication of the exact impact that the tourism industry has on the Australian economy. In gross terms—for that is what I assume people are speaking in—it earns a number of billion dollars in overseas exchange earnings for Australia, but in net terms it is probably much more difficult to measure what the positive impact is.

For example, there is some concern among people who do not understand tourism that the extent of foreign ownership of the industry militates against the positive impact it has on the Australian economy. There is something of a perception—and I do not know how wide of the mark it is—that much of our industry is overseas owned, and therefore people often say that tourists who come here, particularly from Asia, are having a minimal benefit to the Australian economy.

Some very good work has been done by the Bureau of Tourism Research and other organisations to illustrate that that is not the case. I think it would be desirable for the industry to be wholly owned by Australians. There is no doubt that we benefit. I suspect that we mainly benefit at the employment end, regardless of the ownership of the resort or whatever, and the fact that employees of the tourism industry are predominantly Australians—fortunately our immigration laws prevent it from being otherwise—is very desirable. It is a fact that there is a considerable degree of overseas ownership and I think we need to understand the net benefits to the Australian economy from the tourism industry.

There are other issues that come up when you live in a tourism based electorate. A lot of the local infrastructure that is put in place benefits the tourism industry. For example, on the Gold Coast a lot of the public facilities, such as our beaches, service the tourism industry but the costs of upkeep are largely picked up locally. They are not necessarily offset against the ostensible benefits that accrue from the tourism industry.

I think our first recommendation deals broadly with the important question of starting to understand the contribution of tourism to the Australian economy. Until we have a very clear picture of that, and not one that is biased by, say, a vested interest, we will not know where to go with the industry. I think the result would demonstrate clearly that the industry is important to the Australian economy.

There are a number of recommendations in the report that I hope will be picked up quickly by the government. I said in the House when our report was tabled that it would be disappointing if this report was put aside for future budget deliberations. The fact is that the budget consideration is going on now. I do not know the process of that, not having been involved in it, but I would hope that the Minister for Transport (Mr Brereton) will very quickly address a number of the issues that are raised here. He indicated to the parliament yesterday that he had glanced at the report. I hope that he would do more than that in the very short term and that we may see reflected in the coming budget some of the recommendations.

Some of the recommendations are not very expensive. In fact, I think the committee probably bent over backwards to not bring down a report with recommendations that are clearly not acceptable. I think opposition and government members of the committee realised that we had to be responsible in the recommendations that we brought forward. I do not know whether, ultimately, that is the committee's responsibility. I had the feeling that we were to bring down recommendations that we believed were right in terms of the evidence that was presented to us, regardless of the implications for revenue, for the government or whatever. I guess there is a balance there of some sort.

In the end, we brought down 26 recommendations, all of which are eminently supportable and none of which have huge revenue implications for government. However, each of the recommendations has within it some significant benefits for the tourism industry. They are not benefits in the sense that they are things that the tourism industry wants from government. We found with this industry that it is not an industry with a handout mentality. This is not an industry which is saying to the government, `We want help.' It has in fact received minimal assistance from governments in the past.

The industry has grown, in spite of the fact that it has not been heavily subsidised, unlike some other sectors of the Australian economy. In the early days there were relatively few people—names flow off of the top of one's head—who saw the potential of tourism. However, the Keith Williamses of this world saw the potential of tourism and realised that Australia was a great product to sell in the international tourism arena. Tourism has become a successful industry without very much help from government.

The current Australian government, to its credit, certainly upped the ante in terms of its contribution. That probably started with Minister Brown, who, I am delighted to see, remains active in promoting the interests of the industry. He deserves considerable credit for putting the tourism industry on the map, albeit that there were some remarks he might prefer not to have made at the time, I guess. Nevertheless, they achieved their purpose and, at the same time, he put the industry—and himself, I would suggest—on the map.

The government has provided continuing injections of funds to the Australian Tourist Commission, which has been very effective in a lot of activities that it has embarked on in promoting tourism to Australia. But there is still a relatively small amount of money involved in that and, ultimately, the industry promotes itself very well. There are a number of people and a number of tourism bodies that exist on a state level, such as the Queensland Tourist and Travel Corporation, which are very effective marketing organisations. They have minimal funds and are doing a really great job of promoting their particular states. Each state has its own such organisation, and organisations are now being coordinated better. That leads to more efficient spending of money as well.

So the industry has not sought a great deal of government assistance. It does not want assistance. If anything, the report indicates that this is an industry mainly composed of small business people who really want to be able to get on with the job they have. The last thing they want to hear is, `I am from the government, I am here to help you.' In fact, they want to be unhindered by the government. It is a model industry, from that point of view, in that the people in it are committed to it and they are prepared to work very hard.

I could speak at length about any one of these 26 recommendations. I freely admit that I have a vested interest in seeing the government pick up a number of them—not a financial interest, I should underline—because they will certainly benefit my constituents.

There are any number of these, and one could start from the top, but even the recommendation that landscaping and outdoor recreational facilities integral to the tourism experience be eligible for depreciation is one which will represent some small cost to government but is a practical recommendation. Of course, the evidence before us was almost incontrovertible that it should be the case, that there was no real argument against making these sorts of assets depreciable.

We talked about the threshold for immediate income tax write-off for items of plant and equipment to be adjusted annually to allow for inflation. That also would represent a very small cost to revenue but the arguments in favour of that were overwhelming and the arguments against it were virtually nil.

I commend this report to the parliament. I think it is a significant report. The committee worked very hard and was really hands-on. We really got into the tourism industry and, for members of the committee that had not been involved in it before, it was certainly an eye-opener.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Neville Mr P.

TALK.START.PARA: —I was not a member of the committee, but I welcome the opportunity to—

PARA.TAB: A division having been called in the House of Representatives—

PARA.EMPHASIS: Sitting suspended from 12.19 p.m. to 12.31 p.m.

TALK.START.PARA: —As I was saying before the division, I was not a member of the House of Representatives Standing Committee on Banking, Finance and Public Administration, but I have had a long association with the tourist industry. I was particularly interested in a number of areas of tourism which the committee fleshed out, areas which badly needed to be addressed. They include matters such as sales tax, the diesel fuel rebate scheme and the export market development scheme. I was disappointed that the committee did not take on board the federal government's treatment of tourist regions. That is a very important dimension of the promotion of tourism, both domestically and internationally.

PARA.TAB: On the question of sales tax and the various types of vessels, especially those which carry out charter and semi-scheduled activities on the Great Barrier Reef, the committee quite rightly pointed out a number of anomalies in that field. For example, there is a distinction between game fishing vessels and sightseeing vessels which carry under 20 people, and fishing vessels and those vessels that undertake scheduled sightseeing.

One group is charged sales tax on the purchase of the vessel, while the other is not charged at all. This caused a great deal of concern. I do not think the determinants should be within the tourism industry as to the size of the vessel, or necessarily to the scheduling, but rather whether or not it can be demonstrated that that vessel is used exclusively or nearly exclusively for the pursuance of tourist activities.

The dissenting report—and I do not introduce this point in order to break down the bipartisanship of this particular chamber—recommends that the sales tax exemption should be available to genuine bareboat operators for the purchase of vessels and for business use with unscheduled departure and arrival times. Were the government to accept that dissenting report's recommendation, that would address part of the matter. However, I am at a loss to know why it was confined to the bareboat operators and did not include those who genuinely undertake tourism activities in smaller vessels or in vessels that currently do not attract sales tax exemption.

I am also disappointed that the committee skirted over the cellar door wine sampling matter. It said that granting an exemption for cellar door wineries could be administratively complicated because of the difference in the way cellar door tastings are conducted—for example, some charge a tasting fee and others include tasting as part of a food and beverage package. I do not think that should be the determinant. To some extent, that is ducking the issue.

There are all sorts of ways that sampling can be regulated. I will use, as an example, the current system employed by the Australian Taxation Office for tax exemption in the use of a private vehicle. If the user of the vehicle is prepared to keep a log book for 12 or 13 weeks and can demonstrate use of that vehicle for business purposes for 60 to 80 per cent of the time, that is recognised as an income tax deduction. I suggest that it would not be difficult for a winery, over a period of three to six months, to record the number of visitors to the winery and to record the gross amount of wine that was expended for sampling purposes.

I am sure wineries would have a sufficient measure of control to log those figures in some appropriate fashion. It would not matter whether the sampling measurement was in millilitres, ounces or nips. A winery could be given an allocation; it might be, for the sake of simplicity, two nips per person. Even if admission were free there would have to be some sort of ticketing to record the number of visitors to that winery. That times the number of, say, the two nips would determine the amount of wine that the winery could claim to be exempt from sales tax. It seems to me to be a perfectly simple measure.
In my own electorate of Hinkler, we have the famous Bundaberg Rum Distillery—

TALK.START.PARA: —You don't have any wineries.

—We have actually; we have John Gianduzzo's winery, `Tropical Wines', at North Bundaberg. He does not make great wines, but he makes a wide variety of wines based on pineapple, guava, cherries, lemons, and so on—in particular, ginger wine.
—Do you recommend them?
—You are distracting me.

PARA.TAB: Mr DEPUTY SPEAKER (Mr Les Scott)—The member for Fisher should not be interjecting.

TALK.START.PARA: —It is a very good winery and I am pleased to be able to mention that winery as the one winery of its type in my electorate. I will go on to this matter of the cellar door wine samples. I use the Bundaberg Rum Distillery as an example. I recognise that with the Bundaberg Rum Distillery we are in a slightly different field, that of excise. Nevertheless I want to illustrate the point that everyone who comes through the Bundaberg Rum Distillery is issued with a ticket. That ticket entitles them to a nip of the famous Aussie spirit.

PARA.TAB: The distillery has a very simple and clear system of regulation in place. At any time, be it for officers of the sales or excise sector of the taxation department, the number of people going through the distillery can be identified very clearly. I cannot see why a similar system, based on a log book, could not be invoked in wineries so as to allow them to have that form of exemption. I am sad that there is no reference to this in the report, but it might be something that the minister could take on board.

Promotion is the lifeblood of the tourist industry. There have always been a number of anomalies in the matter of sales tax on tourism literature. I know what it is like to have to skirt the boundaries of this particular regulation. I managed a regional tourist authority. When we were promoting the region there was a sales tax exemption on our literature. If we did it on behalf of a commercial operator there was no exemption.

In between, there were various stages. Sometimes you might have a series of attractions in a town and it was always a fine line, when you were printing a series of brochures, whether they were principally to educate and inform, or whether they were to promote a particular tourist location. And whether or not you paid sales tax depended on the way that the Tax Office saw that particular balance falling. It is a pretty artificial distinction and I, for one, would like to see sales tax lifted on all promotional literature for tourism, but especially on literature for overseas.

At the end of the day, it is about bringing more people to this country and stimulating tourism around Australia, because tourism is a great employer and it is one of the few industries that are employing a lot of young people. Anything that can be done to stimulate that, to allow people to enjoy their country and to move freely from area to area, is healthy from the community's point of view and from an employment point of view. And it all comes back to the degree of promotion that an operator can afford.

Another area was the diesel fuel rebate scheme. I was talking to a member of the committee only this morning and he said that there was some ambivalence on the committee about that. The recommendation is that:

SPEECH.PARA: . . . the Diesel Fuel Rebate Scheme be reviewed to clarify its objectives and to investigate alternatives to ensure equity and minimise distortions in its application.
I go along with that, as far as it goes. But, again, to some extent it ducks the real issue. There are great anomalies out there. For example, a fishing vessel receives the rebate; however, a

tourist vessel that might even be going out for a fishing expedition will not receive the rebate. And a tourist ship taking people along the Queensland coast would not be exempt, but one going to Fiji would. Broadly, I accept the recommendation, but feel that it should have gone a lot further.

PARA.TAB: As a former tourist operative, I have always found that the export market development grant is a galling thing. Even Austrade is somewhat contradictory in evidence that it has given before committees on this matter, saying that, because there is a captive market, there is some justification for having a reduced rate of 25 per cent for the tourist industry. I heartily endorse the recommendation of the committee that this be lifted to 50 per cent.

I would like to see the scheme go further. The threshold of 30,000 is unrealistic for smaller and medium operators. I know the argument is put forward that you can form conglomerates and groups, and so on. But the better way to attack that would be to bring down a smaller threshold and allow the state-recognised regional tourism authorities to participate in the scheme and to take groups of smaller operators into marketing forays. I do not think the size of the operator is so important, as long as the promotion itself has enough critical mass when it gets onto the overseas market.

In the few minutes remaining to me, I want to mention one area that the committee missed and that was federal grants to regional tourist authorities. I know that some would argue that tourist authorities may be able to extract funds indirectly, through the new REDO scheme under the regional development program. My view is that tourism is one of Australia's leading industries. It is the one that is generating employment, and if the Commonwealth is going to enter into the field of regional development it should be looking at practitioner funding for regional tourist authorities.

One of the things that militates against the success of regional tourist authorities is that all the programs—be they the REDO ones or the ones under the Department of Tourism—all come back to applying for funds on a project basis. It is as if the federal government, like a lot of the state governments, wants white knights out there to run their programs, but will not acknowledge that that requires a management team, expertise, core funding activities, equipment and liaison with members.

We must remember that these tourist authorities take a huge burden off government. Tourist authorities in the Queensland model alone are generally made up of state government input, local authority input and private operator input. To that extent, that is a huge burden lifted from government. I think that should be recognised by the federal government and a form of practitioner funding should be available to those tourist authorities which have proper marketing programs recognised by their state governments. I would recommend that a figure of about $50,000 per year would not be unrealistic, bearing in mind that the state governments in most states give between $100,000 and $200,000. I thank you for your indulgence, Mr Deputy Speaker.

TALK.START.PARA: —I am very pleased to have the opportunity to join this debate on the report Taxing relaxing from the House of Representatives Standing Committee on Banking, Finance and Public Administration. By all indications, the committee worked well. It was a committee which looked very closely at its terms of reference and I gather that it was run on a fairly bipartisan basis.

PARA.TAB: Like my colleague the honourable member for Hinkler (Mr Neville), I was not a member of the committee, but as I represent the Sunshine Coast and as I represent many other areas in south-east Queensland which have a very vital tourism industry, my electorate has a great interest in the outcome of this report and, more importantly, in the government's response to it. I would also say that the south Burnett, an area which I inherited under the redistribution, also has a very strong and growing tourism industry and that tourism industry needs extra taxes like a hole in the head.

I think it is important to look very closely at the terms of reference of the committee. They were outlined by the chairman, the honourable member for Calare (Mr Simmons), when he spoke in the main chamber. He said that the report addresses three terms of reference which required the committee to examine the level of taxation levied on the tourism industry: firstly, to assess whether the taxation regime impacted unfairly on tourism relative to other industries; secondly, to identify any inequities relative to other industries in the application of specific taxation measures to the tourism industry; and, thirdly, to establish whether the taxation regime placed Australia's tourism industry at a competitive disadvantage relative to the taxation regime of competitor countries. Of course, those terms of reference could well have been expanded but they were not. The fact that the committee had limited terms of reference has meant that the committee was not able to do as wide ranging a job as it would no doubt have liked to do.

I noticed also that the committee travelled widely into areas where tourism is a major industry, but unfortunately did not visit the Sunshine Coast, which is one of Australia's premier areas for tourism. I might mention that 1,132,000 people visit the Sunshine Coast each year as tourists. They stay there for a total of 5,132,000 nights and they spend over $435 million. So that is a very vital and very important industry on the Sunshine Coast. It is an area people visit regularly. An enormous number of people continue to come to the Sunshine Coast to enjoy our very many attractions. I am very disappointed that the committee did not visit this area, which has been deemed by those skilled in statistics to be effectively Australia's 12th largest city.

I would particularly like to say that I am pleased that the committee has come down very strongly on the side of the coalition in our opposition to a bed tax on the tourism industry. The government, of course, is being quite coy as to what is included in the budget. We have not got any definite word—

TALK.START.PARA: —Your comrades in the NT—the CLP—have got a bed tax.
—We are totally opposed to what the Labor government is seeking to do here. The bed tax would cripple the tourism industry and would cost jobs.

—Order! We will not have a debate across the chamber. The honourable member for the Northern Territory (Mr Snowdon) will cease interjecting. The honourable member for Fisher will direct his comments through the chair.

—After 12 years in government there are 800,000 people out of work. If the government imposes its bed tax it will put even more people out of work. That will be an absolute disgrace, and I hope that the government adopts the recommendation of the committee report which we are now debating. That is a very strong recommendation opposed to a bed tax.

PARA.TAB: We are also pleased to see that the coalition has received support in its call for an end to the discrimination against the tourism industry under the export market development grants scheme. The shadow minister for tourism, Senator Warwick Parer, has called on the government to act on the recommendations contained in the report and we are certainly hoping that the government will act favourably in relation to these particular recommendations. They are very important as far as the growth of our tourism industry is concerned.

It is interesting to note that this committee was, as all House of Representatives committees are, dominated by the Labor Party and yet, despite that, this committee has come down against a bed tax and it has also supported the coalition call for an end to discrimination against the tourism industry under the export market development grant scheme.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Labor Party doesn't impose a bed tax; only conservatives impose a bed tax. What does Grant Tambling say about it?
—Order! The honourable member for the Northern Territory.

—It is important to recognise that this report recommends that the accommodation sector not be singled out for taxation and that all single service providers have equal access to the EMDG scheme at the full rate of 50c in the dollar. It is interesting that the report also rejects a call from the Australian Council of Social Service in January for a services tax, including a bed tax, on the hotel and resort industry.

PARA.TAB: Unfortunately, ministers in both houses of the parliament have refused to rule out the possibility of a bed tax and it is now the government's responsibility. I would like, again, publicly to call on the parliamentary secretary at the table to rule out a federal bed tax, which would cripple this growth industry and cut jobs.

TALK.START.PARA: —Don't talk rubbish in here. Wait for the budget.

—The government has actually undertaken, through Access Economics, a secret study of the impact of such a tax on the tourism industry. The government had to acknowledge that the study has been undertaken, after a public servant revealed its existence to a Senate estimates committee. But unfortunately this government, particularly through the Minister for Tourism (Mr Lee), has flatly refused to release details of the study to the industry or anyone else.
—Wait for the budget.

—This government is being really secret.This government is deceiving the Australian people and the parliamentary secretary at the table says again that he will not tell us whether we are going to have a bed tax. You will not say whether you are going to slug the Australian tourism industry and whether you are going to throw people out of work, as indeed you have put 800,000 people out of work over the last 12 years.
—Order! The honourable member for Fisher should direct his comments through the chair, and the honourable member for the Northern Territory should cease interjecting or I will deal with him.

—A number of questions have been asked of government ministers and they have simply come forward with the same inadequate response as we heard a couple of seconds ago from the parliamentary secretary at the table. Senator Parer has said that the threat of a bed tax was already damaging the tourism industry. Mr Deputy Speaker, being an assiduous reader of the Courier-Mail you would have noticed that the possible sale of the Brisbane Hilton Hotel has been thwarted because of the government's proposed bed tax.
—Ha, ha.

—It has. The honourable member should stop laughing. It has been made quite clear that the $100 million sale of the Brisbane Hilton Hotel has been scrapped because of speculation over this iniquitous tax. The threat still hangs over the industry and, indeed, it is crippling confidence and badly retarding investment. The uncertainty is one of the worst things. The uncertainty is, indeed, costing jobs. It is stopping investment. What the government should really do is come clean, after having leaked the proposal in the first place, and tell us whether people on the Sunshine Coast, people throughout Fisher and, indeed, people throughout Mr Deputy Speaker's own electorate of Oxley are going to be slugged with a bed tax.

PARA.TAB: I might add that in the run-up to the last election we had as part of our Fightback plan the introduction of a GST—

TALK.START.PARA: —Of 15 per cent!

—Of 15 per cent. But we were going to abolish seven Labor taxes; we were going to slash personal income tax and along with the abolition of those taxes we were also going to scrap fuel tax. But this government is simply talking about the introduction of a bed tax on top of the already very many taxes imposed on the tourism industry. That is why I am very pleased that this committee has wholeheartedly endorsed the position of the coalition, which is totally opposed to what the government has been suggesting.

PARA.TAB: The Prime Minister (Mr Keating) himself has refused to rule out a bed tax. In answer to a question from the shadow Treasurer recently he simply said, as the parliamentary secretary did a moment ago, `Wait for the budget.'

TALK.START.PARA: —Wait for the budget.

—`Wait for the budget,' he says; and so at this time we have the workers involved in the tourism industry deeply concerned over the adverse impact that such a bed tax would have on their income and on their jobs. The Prime Minister has taken a shifty and evasive attitude, but Senator Evans has also confirmed that the government is looking to introduce a bed tax; so, whichever way we look at it, we are likely to have a bed tax. There has been so much speculation around that the government has commissioned a report, but I ask that at this late stage the government take on board what this committee has suggested: that the bed tax proposal should be dropped, because tourism is really a vital industry.

PARA.TAB: Tourism is one of Australia's growth industries. What we should be doing is getting taxes off the back of industry in such a way as to encourage its expansion—particularly the tourism industry. With the growth in ecotourism, particularly, we are finding that tourism is playing a greater and greater role in the economy. I do not think anyone in the parliament would deny the importance of the tourism industry, and that is why it is absolutely vital that the government adopt the recommendations of the report currently before the Committee.

Here we have an industry which is largely a clean industry; an industry which encourages economic development; an industry which encourages respect for the environment; and, most importantly, an industry which encourages jobs. I would ask the government to think long and hard before it introduces yet another proposal which is going to cost jobs and which is going to inhibit the growth of this vital industry.

What the government needs to be doing is encouraging the tourism industry, not working against it. That is why as a coalition we strongly support the recommendations of this report currently before the Committee. We would ask the government to adopt those recommendations, particularly the two that I have mentioned before. I will repeat them once again. We want the government to reject the bed tax.
Mr Snowdon interjecting—

TALK.START.PARA: —I would invite the parliamentary secretary, on behalf of the government, to say to the tourism industry and the workers of Australia that we are not going to have a bed tax in the budget. Further, I ask that he assure us that the government is going to accept the recommendation that there be an end to discrimination against the tourism industry under the export market development grants scheme.

PARA.TAB: Those who have read the report would have seen that there are 26 recommendations. There was a majority of government members on the committee. There were two dissenting reports, one by all of the coalition members and another by the honourable member for Dawson (Mr Braithwaite). When the government is preparing its response to the report, I would ask that it look not only at the majority report but at the minority report as well.

What we need to do is to make sure that this vital Australian industry is able to continue to grow, is able to continue to provide jobs and is able to continue to boost the Australian economy. The last thing this industry needs is a bed tax. The industry also needs an end to discrimination under the export market development grants scheme. I commend the report of the committee to the House, and I ask the government, very seriously, to accept the report of the committee, particularly with respect to the bed tax and the ending of discrimination under the export market development grants scheme. I thank the Committee.
Debate (on motion by Mr Snowdon) adjourned.
